 About Sins Of The Demon RPGFollow the journey of Kenshi, a wandering demon hunter, and his brother, a demon cat seeking a way to return to his true form. Can they find a way to end the curse and save Lanistra? The Story in Sins Of The Demon RPGYou know that game that makes you skip your bed because you want to continue playing to see what happens next? This game is one of those. The story itself is quite simple if you take the whole bunch, but seeing how the stuff were presented to the player makes it much more immersive and touching, I simply loved how the things developed and at the end I had me like "Gosh, I want more of this". The only things that bugs me is about some realism questions like that 10 yr. old boy fighting at your side, but still, I must use the "fantasy creative freedom" in order to nullify the value of these question of mine. The Level DesignI'm a bit too overcritical about this since mapmaking is my biggest skill in RPG Maker, but still, this game managed to deliver a well made "network" styled maps that gives a good immersion and that I had a lot of fun exploring, for those who don't know that it, is that when maps are strictly connected one to the others, a.k.a., no World Map for travelling and etcoetera (This is not an actual a precise definition but you all must have got the idea right now). What I didn't like a bit was that some times the map feels pretty empty, in the sense like, there could be more details in some parts, but that's okay (I tend to give too much detail to my maps sometimes).Also, the whole country feels pretty small, I think that the developers could've used some graphical resources to make things more countinous. The GameplayOkay, what pisses me off as a developer is to adjust the gameplay in order to keep the difficulty okay (not too easy but also not too hard), this game make things works well, except that sometimes you can power level with ease by leaving and entering on it again. My suggestion to this kind of "respawn" is to respawn only certain mobs on the map, let me say, one third of all the mobs? That sounds like pretty reasonable for me, anything to difficult the power level can be used to that, not to mention that there's a way to farm money by making pork buns, and with that, I got like the main character with an ATK of 220 (I could've done more, but I had little time then). Recapitulating, the gameplay fits pretty well the game's purpose, the only complaint are those mathematical and technical questions about leveling up and money making, that doesn't actually "break" the game.All in  All Sins Of The Demon RPG	 is a very nice RPG Game!8/10 From Me Sweep

												I just finished this game, and without a doubt, this is the saddest ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed game I have ever played, let alone the saddest role playing game. The story in this game is extremely well written, and the world, the characters, and just the whole setting are engrossing and will draw you in. But it's all sad. You have happy moments, but in the end it all ends up being sad. It is also full of several really neat twists to the plot, although a couple of them you can see coming from a bit far away. It doesn't diminish their quality however.The rest of the game supports the story well. It might be an RPG Maker title, but the maps are well done, and all characters sprites are a pleasure to look at. The one thing you may have a problem with is the repetiveness and backtracking, as the entire game takes place on one series of interconnected maps spawninng about six areas with maps in between to travel between them. So you will tread the same ground repeatedly.The battles in the game are enjoyable and fast paced as it is set permanently to an active time battle system. All your commands must be chosen quickly as the enemies will not wait for you. The game has no additional equipment to buy, only items, and also several recipes which you can use to cook healing and stat boosting items. Money is easy to find as you can find various items to sell and then you can either buy items or cooking supplies.Although the enemies do suffer from a bit of repetitiveness as well. The games story does revolve around the seven deadly sins, but you will mainly be seeing enemies based on sloth, greed, wrath, and pride during the game; enemies based on lust, gluttony, and envy, only show up in single areas as you progress, and outside of this you fight bandits. Boss battles, outside of the first one, are usually against one of the more powerful enemies you haven't fought yet, or a huge group of enemies you normally wouldn't encounter together.I got this as part of a $0.65 bundle of titles but you should buy it on its own if any of this sounds appealing to you. Just remember to keep some kleenex handy; you'll understand why.A heavy hearted, teary eyed, JRPG battling, recommendation [full of sadness :( ]

												TL;DR: Probably the best storytelling in an RPG ever. Play this game.I don't usually write reviews, but damn, this game.Probably the best writing I've ever seen, and I've played a LOT of RPGs during the last 10 years. Nothing is what it seems. The story is amazingly well-written and executed, the dialogues are amazing, and although I was skeptical at first, the skits give you a completely different feel for the game. For the first time in an RPG do you actually see the party bond during the journey, intead of just suddenly being BFFs after a couple of stupid cutscenes. The characters idly chat, joke, make silly comments, bond and get to know each other in a way I have never seen before in an RPG. The closest thing to this I've ever played was To the moon.I really can't stress how good the story in this game is. Nothing ends up being the way you thought it would, and you constantly have to reconsider past events. The game does so much to get you in touch with the characters, which just makes the events that happen so much more touching. And my god, the dialog is INTELLIGENT. I am so tired of being insulted by "Oh, no, who would do such a thing?! What a jerk!" and the likes, but this game. THIS GAME! Every single line made sense and felt natural. The characters didn't feel like they had the minds of 3-year-olds, but of real people. Japanese RPGs often have so cringy lines, and even English ones rarely have writing this good. The game is also ridiculously long for such a cheap game. 1€ for over 10 hours of story? This was worth more than that, but I'm afraid I'd never have found the game if it wasn't so cheap in the first place...That being said, the game has its flaws. The combat system is a bit bland, and there are few abilities and interaction between them. You'll almost always just paralyze/tackle/blind the enemy and bash them to death with a couple of double-hit attacks. At some point you also unlock the ability to craft stat items which even sell for more than the ingredients you need for them, so you can essentially get infinite money and stats by just cooking repeatedly. This was... boring. I ended up using Cheat Engine to skip the grinding and max out my stats simply to advance the story faster. Luckily, you can avoid most battles (it was an excellent choice to not have random battles!) and even the bosses aren't terribly difficult once you unlock the stat items and grind cooking for a few minutes. Still, the focus is on the excellent storytelling and writing, and the game is more than worth your time despite the combat system not being too interesting.

However, since parts of the world only become accessible once the story has progressed further, exploration is limited.Same goes for the RPG battles. There are no random encounters and monsters are always visigle on the map. Once defeated they disappear but respawn if you reenter an area.Battle system itself is turn-based utilizing an ATB, active time battle system. Similar to Final Fantasy games that used this system it means, that once an an attack bar has been filled up several options including attack, skill become available. Just don't forget that enemies won't wait their turn and attack once they can attack i.e. their bar has filled up. This makes battles become quite hectic at times. One oddity need to be mentioned however and that is quite a miss rate on attacks (both regular and skill attacks). While those misses happen random, they used to happen way more often than in other games and can become quite annoying at times.Another downside for some may the absence weapon customizations or ability of changing gear at all. There are skills that will unlock once the characters reach a certain level, but the player will get all once they reach level 10. Leveling up more will "only" increase stats, which can be done by finding certain recipes and crafting food items too.Overall this game still deserves a recommendation if you are looking for a RPG with focus on story telling and less focus on fighting will find a fair adventure here. 												This game is a mixed bag for me. Its story is one of the best I've ever seen in an RPG maker game. It resolves every issue it initiates, the characters and their interactions are more likable than not, and the world is designed in such a way that the you can continue the story or complete most side quests at your leisure . I also love the way that the game handles flashbacks. Most other games will simply tell you a characters backstory through dialogue, or a cinematic with some sort of visual effect. This game will actually put you in control of a character to see their past from their perspective. Not only does this make the story-telling more interesting, but the few minutes in between story events during flashbacks give you a chance to save or explore the world of the past between loads of exposition.I really don't have anything to say against the story. My main problem is the game mechanics. Characters can attack and use special attacks that cost some SP, but most of the special attacks consist of stronger attacks. Some can raise ally stats and lower those of enemies, but thats about as deep as it goes. Even the abilites available late game consist of changing stats and strong attacks. And enemies use similiar abilities, give or take a status effect or two. There aren't any elemental weaknesses or skill trees, and the worst part is that there isn't even equipment! If you check a characters status you'll see their default equipment, but there is no way to upgrade or change it. Another problem is that the "active time" battle system might as well be a turn based one.  Whenever characters aren't acting an action gauge will fill up. Once it's full that character can take an action. But there isn't any way to choose the order in which your characters will take their turns, so the only thing that you can do other than move your characters in the default order, is to wait for the enemy to move first and then move your characters in the default order. This leaves very little room for strategy and the way the game handles items and money doesn't make it any better. One problem is the cooking mechanic. It's a simple crafting mechanic that allows you to combine ingredient items to make food items (most of which act as healing items). However some ingedients cost significantly less than the food items can sell for, so you can abuse this to make a fortune buying low and selling high. On top of that, you'll eventually unlock recipes that allow you to make stat increasing items that you can make to you're hearts content with the money shopkeepers will give you for food made with their own ingredients. At this point its a question of if you want to stock up on healing items or raise your characters stats to broken levels, but there is absolutely nothing stopping you from doing both. The fact that the game doesn't give you any incentive to play fair and gives you every opportunity to exploit its mechanics makes me think the developers knew that most players would just want to get on with the story. All that said, if you're looking to follow a decent story for about ten hours you'll probably enjoy this game. If you'll looking for a fun battle system you definitely won't. If you're looking for both you'll likely have very mixed feelings after finishing this game, and that is where I stand as of now.

												Let me start off by saying I was very pleasantly surprised by this game. I find it very difficult to find myself enraptured by games these days, outside of primarily the Souls series. So when I was browsing the store, the picture caught my eye, but as I read up on reviews for this I decided I wanted to try it out. Perhaps I would find something that would capture my attention the way every game used to when I was younger.Boy, was I right.I will be blunt. The story is not original, though that does not mean it isnt interesting. The art design is extremely familiar, given that many people will be reminded of their days playing pokemon. However, the intense combat learning curve (which at first feels like a wild rollercoaster ride with no safety harness, but then gradually turns into a race that challenges your reflexes) was incredibly stimulating. I also enjoyed a great portion of the dialogue. For example, (this is a generic encounter, in now way related to spoilerific content) there is a house in the main city that you can go into. Inside there is a gentleman. If you approach him and speak to him, the only thing he says is "Get out of my house." Its such a simple line, and yet I found myself laughing hysterically at the proposition of having a character give me such a realistic response in a game that is anything but. Remember all those houses you just randomly entered in pokemon to try and find stuff because you felt like it? How many times do you think youd be told "Get out of my house" in real life if you did the same thing? Its little things like that that turn something plain into something charming and captivating.The characters werent the most impressive bunch, but there were a few who stuck out as well thought out.This game isnt particularly great at anything, but the overall experience is.... satisfying, and endearing. Yes you may have to grind, but there are loops and tricks you can use to dramatically decrease the time spent grinding,if you're clever. Is it worth it? Absolutely.  10/10 would play again

												NOTE: This game has been giften to me by EQ Free Games during the alpha phase of the game for the purpose of spreading the joy of this game when I enjoyed it. But since I received the game as a gift, I thought I would give it a try. I had the same feeling like you would have right now at the first few minutes of the game, but I decided to continue playing.And I'm glad I did.This is not just a ''simple RPG created in an editor to make some easy money'', although the graphics might express that. But the looks of the game are misleading, because the true potential of this game lies deeper: The story.The story of Kenshi and his demon cat is told in such a good way, with plot-twists and jokes in all corners of the game. There is just so much dialog put into these lovely characters that you know that this RPG isn't something made to exploit you, but to enjoy you, to make you laugh, to make you cry, but most important: to let you have a good time. And that's a big plus for me.Of course, story isn't everything. Apart from the story, the rest of the game is pretty ''okay'' in the sense that it isn't perfect, but it does the job. For exemple, the combat system is pretty cool with all the different classes you find during the game, but it's pretty basic (apart from the fact it's a semi-real time combat system). So are the graphics and the exploration. It's not perfect, but it still creates the atmosphere needed for a nice RPG like this.To summarise my review: This RPG is pretty basic in a lot of aspects, but the story is beyond extraordinary. And I think that is the most enjoyable aspect of this game and a RPG in general. It just helps to fill the atmosphere so much. The rest of the game definitely has potential to be improved here and there (the devs work on it.), but in its current state it's still one of the best games I played in a while, especially for this price.Score: 7.9/10

My playtime: 09:38:41 (based on internal clock)Grindy Achievement: No.Optional Achievement: Yes (5 achievements).Developer Response: ~24h (in selected threads).IntroSins Of The Demon RPG is a RPG Maker game which focuses on the story. There are barely any bosses in the game and all fights are optional. This game only has ~7 monsters (excluding the boss) which are used throughout the game.MusicAlthough some music can be pleasant, most of the music are terrible. The music in the main menu sounds like a broken record, and i especially hate the music when there are a loud and long buzzing sound on it. The music in the Kishan hill is too low compared to it.GraphicsThe graphics in this game is tied to japanese theme, although it might be nice if the demon realm has a different feel to make it feel like having a different style on it. However, i must say that the demon realm sprite and mapping are done beautifully and that's the map that i loved the most.The other map, on the other hand, are decent. However, some paths are just too small, and the NPCs can block the path. You won't imagine how many times i'm stuck waiting in a certain spot just to wait for the NPC to move because i'm trying to talk to the same NPCs everytime to look for sidequest. The mapping in the hills are also too large and it's taking too much time to travel around because you have to go through that place every time since that place is the one who connects most cities.The dialogue length is also not appropriate with the dialogue box. Although i don't really mind with the trailing spaces in the dialogue box, i found a dialogue box which trims the dialogue text.A monster in Linshia mountain is also placed in an unreachable place, making it to be useless.The cutscenes didn't record the opened chests and will always shows as unopened. It might be confusing at first, but i can bear with it.StoryThis game mostly focused on the story. In the third chapter, you'll mostly pressed action button just to read through the story with minimal action. However, it's not that boring to listen except that the skits are too long and some dialogue in the skits seems to be forced in order to make all members in the party talk. The hypens are also causing delay, which will make the reading to take longer.The story itself is about a curse which invaded a land which will turn people into one of the 7 deadly sins whenever they commit it. However, the sins placement seems to be rushed near the ending which makes some to be placed for a very short amount of time.The cutscenes in this game took very long, especially if you have to wait for someone to enter or leave the map. However, the story itself is very interesting to hear and quite unpredictable. I also like the game concept.All quests will be logged in the journal. Besides the main quest, there are optional side quest which will be triggered at a certain point. There is no indication for the trigger though, so if you don't have the info, you have to talk to all villagers to find one. The reward will vary from nothing to a great sum of money.BattleThere is no equipment in this game, meaning that you'll only depend on your stat and level to finish the game.This game is using turn based battle. However, the game won't wait for you to finish your turn before moving. The battle lags when there are too many enemies and party members in the battle and since there is no auto-attack option, you'll have to spam your action button to finish your turn fast.There are skills in this game and the skills will consume SP. The SP will be recovered as you are hitting your enemies with normal attack and you can learn a skill which can recover it faster later on.The battle in this game is rigged. Although there is no random encounters, the number of enemies in one map is just too much. Not to mention that you don't have to level that much just to finish the game. There are cheap craftable permanent stat items which can cap your stats and net you quick money.The transition between the sloth to greed demons as the common monster in the area are balanced. However, the transition to wrath demons are just too much. Greed demons start with 200 HP and wrath demons start with 2000 HP. Not to mention that wrath demons used to be a boss in the previous fight. However, after you can and buff yourself up with the stat booster, all fights will seem like a joke in your eyes (1 to 2 fights to beat the boss? lol).However, the fight in the early Chapter 3 (Ishraul's past) looks ridiculous because the character is too weak to kill the enemies with a normal attack alone and his spell is disabled.CookingThere is a cooking system in this game which will allow you to cook from a simple HP "potions" to a permanent stat boost item. However, you can only cook in 1, 5, and 10 quantity. An option to choose how many do you want to cook (like.. 99 for example) would be nice.Pros:- Story focused RPG- Cooking system- Side questsCons:- No bulk cooking- Too many enemies in one mapConclusionThis is a long RPG Maker game which focuses on the story instead of battling.Should you buy this game?Yes.If you love RPG Maker game with a solid story, this is your game. However, the other aspects are decent or just not good enough so if you really care about them, you better think twice before buying it.

												I'm really twisted about this game.It started out very well: with small maps you could cover well, a small cast of characters and a well-arranged questlog for sidequests. The latter were especially nice as some were marked as time-sensitive, some were only unlocked after finishing a location, some had special rewards like recipes. The idea of collecting recipes so you can renew your own supplies is a nice feat of the game, although the more complicated recipes build on the simple ones - if you missed one, unlucky you. (or me, in that case)Another spur to explore the little world are treasure maps that depict a tiny part of a local map and usually contain a little reward if you find it.As the story of Shiro and Shinto (yes, confusable names are, unfortunately, a bit common) continues, you are also given "skits" if you press Q, which means you can see how the characters interact. This gives them more depth and also inserts facesets and mimic, so you feel like you actually know these people. There has generally been a lot of work with facesets/chipsets, for example tears or small wounds, which I really appreciate since those are details that are easily overlooked.The fighting-system works well if you are slightly stronger than your opponent. Once you need to select items or techniques, you are immediately under pressure since your character loses the chance to strike back - if you're unlucky, you can select your healing item, but you'll be killed before you can use it. That has been bothersome, but you are healed when you save your game, which eases grinding. I didn't need to do that a lot, fortunately, since you can escape from battles by running away quite easily.So there's the plot.Like I said, I had great fun during the first chapter, where the game establishes its world and its great conflicts - giving into sins is human, but it turns you into a demon without hope for cure. And basically everyone can turn into a demon once he or she is just pushed enough. The two brothers and main protagonists look for help for Shinto without really knowing what is wrong with him, but they have faith that he hasn't done anything terrible, and Shinto yearns to be human, not being mistaken for a cat.The majority of the second chapter was enjoyable, too, which new relationships forming and the secret behind Isharul's curse slowly coming to light.And then there was the rest of the game, the third chapter, where the game basically turned into a graphic novel and your only part in the game is walking from cutscene to cutscene. To make everything worse, the characters suddenly turn into stereotypes: everyone is basically the same, everybody is good at heart and likes cooking and then there was that girl. Forgiveness, once so important about the concept, is only granted to characters the game "likes", plotholes are not explained (like how Shinto and Shiro could ever forget about their past...).I'll still give this a positive rating because I really didn't pay a lot and it started out so well, and there are some good ideas and a lot of work in it. But the plot... deviated, and if I want a graphic novel, I get one.

However, the sins placement seems to be rushed near the ending which makes some to be placed for a very short amount of time.The cutscenes in this game took very long, especially if you have to wait for someone to enter or leave the map. However, the story itself is very interesting to hear and quite unpredictable. I also like the game concept.All quests will be logged in the journal. Besides the main quest, there are optional side quest which will be triggered at a certain point. There is no indication for the trigger though, so if you don't have the info, you have to talk to all villagers to find one. The reward will vary from nothing to a great sum of money.BattleThere is no equipment in this game, meaning that you'll only depend on your stat and level to finish the game.This game is using turn based battle. However, the game won't wait for you to finish your turn before moving. The battle lags when there are too many enemies and party members in the battle and since there is no auto-attack option, you'll have to spam your action button to finish your turn fast.There are skills in this game and the skills will consume SP. The SP will be recovered as you are hitting your enemies with normal attack and you can learn a skill which can recover it faster later on.The battle in this game is rigged. Although there is no random encounters, the number of enemies in one map is just too much. Not to mention that you don't have to level that much just to finish the game. There are cheap craftable permanent stat items which can cap your stats and net you quick money.The transition between the sloth to greed demons as the common monster in the area are balanced. However, the transition to wrath demons are just too much. Greed demons start with 200 HP and wrath demons start with 2000 HP. Not to mention that wrath demons used to be a boss in the previous fight. However, after you can and buff yourself up with the stat booster, all fights will seem like a joke in your eyes (1 to 2 fights to beat the boss? lol).However, the fight in the early Chapter 3 (Ishraul's past) looks ridiculous because the character is too weak to kill the enemies with a normal attack alone and his spell is disabled.CookingThere is a cooking system in this game which will allow you to cook from a simple HP "potions" to a permanent stat boost item. However, you can only cook in 1, 5, and 10 quantity. An option to choose how many do you want to cook (like.. 99 for example) would be nice.Pros:- Story focused RPG- Cooking system- Side questsCons:- No bulk cooking- Too many enemies in one mapConclusionThis is a long RPG Maker game which focuses on the story instead of battling.Should you buy this game?Yes.If you love RPG Maker game with a solid story, this is your game. However, the other aspects are decent or just not good enough so if you really care about them, you better think twice before buying it.
